title: Connections are the key for executive MBA graduates
text:
“The blocks are predominantly taught in two-week intensives, which I think makes it manageable for a busy executive, and that’s the cohort we are looking to target,” he says. “The fact that we seek to uphold really high standards of experience to get into the program means that the cohort itself is very strong.

“Because we have travelled together to interesting and new places and are living together for extended periods, we really get to know each other well.”

Guy Farrow, Sydney managing partner of executive search firm Heidrick & Struggles, says employers show a preference for graduates who have been fully engaged in their business studies, over those who dip in and out of courses.

The more intense the program, the more it focuses the mind and allows students to develop strong networks.

“The first [reason] is just the immersion in thinking about frameworks and strategies and business all day long, for a defined period of time,” Farrow says. “The other one is the cohort that you’re with throughout the program. The best business schools always choose a great deal of diversity.

“The richness of the learning that comes through the way people from different backgrounds think about problem-solving in a business is one of the attributes you get through the full‑time program.”

Advertisement

EMBA and MBA alumni believe the course has improved their career prospects, but EMBA grads have the edge when it comes to seeing an improvement in the way they perform their current job. Two out of three EMBA graduates believe they can do their current jobs more effectively, against 55 per cent of MBA graduates.

For Tim Sleep, Australian managing director at executive talent firm Odgers Berndtson, simply undertaking the study says a lot about potential candidates.

“I think any senior executive who has demonstrated continuous learning throughout their career is a positive, and the MBAs and EMBAs both tick that box,” he says. “The challenge, though, is that it’s becoming an increasingly competitive market.

“What we’re seeing is people are hiring more and more for mindset over skill set, so there’s more of a focus on, ‘Are you curious? Do you have a propensity to understand what's going to win in the market tomorrow?’

“An MBA or EMBA is good, it demonstrates the type of character you have, but you’re rarely hired for the skills that you learn on that course. Are they valuable? Can they be of use? Sure, but that’s more by luck than by design.”
description: The high cost of an EMBA is offset by the value of the close networks it offers.
